articleinfo.title: Brief technical description of the Ediffah search engine

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The name Ediffah is an acronym of the Swedish name (Ediffah -- En digital infrastruktur f√∂r forskningsbibliotekens arkiv- och handskriftssamlingar) of a project aiming at providing an infrastructure for cataloging and searching archival collections at Swedish research libraries

listitem.para: EAD Authoring. Most partners are currently using Note Tab Pro

Publishing system. We use a simple web based interface permitting catalogers to upload EAD finding aids to a database. The database is a file system based data store supporting the following operations:
Insert
Remove
Update (implemented as a remove+insert while maintaining record ID)
Hide, which makes a finding aid invisible to end users while still accessible and searchable for editorial staff.
Publish, which makes a previously hidden finding-aid visible for end users.

An indexing system whereby inserted finding aids are mead searchable in two databases, one containg the public ones and the other those that are hidden. The publishing and indexing system communicates through a simple printer queue like communication systems. The publishing system thus spools incremental requests for either removal or insertion of finding aids into the index. Since each job submitted to the indexer is very small, the queue is flushed once a minute.

A search system permitting end users and client systems search the database. This system comprises two components
A server system
A web based client or gateway
Currently the client and server communicates through Z39.50 using XML record syntax.

sect1.title: Software used
sect1.para: Very little software has been written for implementing Ediffah. The whole system consists of about 900 lines object oriented perl libraries implementing the abstractions behind the file store and user interfaces. These lines are used in another about 500 lines of scripts implementing the publishing and indexing systems and the communication protocol between the two. Finally the end user interface, the client/gateway, consists of about 900 lines of php code originally written for other purposes.
The bulk of the system is open source software readily available on the Internet and the whole system will run on a simple PC under Linux.

sect2.title: The search engine and indexing principles
sect2.para: The actual search engine is idZebra, also from indexdata. To understand exactly how the server is used requires some knowledge on the principles of Z39.50. Elsewhere I have described in some detail the principles I used for building a similar service, namely St Laurentius Digital Manuscript Library. Please note that things has changed significantly since that system was implemented. The most important differences being that XML has become a common record syntax in the Z39.50 community and that idZebra thus has evolved significantly to support that. It now has a good support for connecting XML constructs to Z39.50 search attributes via the XML Path language.

The powerful feature of idZebra to permit configuring search attributes to contain sets of search attributes which I describe in [6] is also used extensively in the Ediffah search engine. The configuration files used are in the syntax described in the Zebra manual. For those technically minded, the ead.abs file, defining how EAD tags and XML constructs are tied to the indexes and search attributes are available for inspection, and so is the extended subset of the BIB-1 attribute set we are using bib1.att
